I. Magnesia supported catalysts G.E. Vrieland, C.B. Murchison * Catalysis Lab, Central Research and Development, The Dow Chemical Company, 1776 Bldg., Midland, M148674, USA Received 31 May 1995; revised 23 August 1995; accepted 23 August 1995 Abstract A potential new process to styrene monomer from n-butane consists of oxidation of n-butane to butadiene followed by dimerization of butadiene to 4-vinylcyclohexene (VCH) and oxydehydrogen- ation of VCH to styrene. In this paper we report a catalyst which provides 40%-50% conversion of n-butane at 80% selectivity to butadiene and the n-butenes when exposed to 5-10 s pulses of n-butane followed by air regeneration. The optimum catalyst consists of 15%-25% MoO3 dispersed on MgO. The addition of small amounts of alkali metal compounds are used to minimize the production of carbon oxides. Characterization of these catalysts by laser Raman spectroscopy and XANES indicates that octahedral polymolybdates and micro crystals of MgMoO4 are initially the major species at molybdenum loadings corresponding to maximum activity on fresh catalyst. Designed experiments have resulted in models predicting the relationship of selectivity and conversion 'for various process conditions. Keywords: Butane; Butadiene; Butene; Oxydehydrogenation; Molybdate; Magnesia 1. Introduction Raw materials account for greater than 80% of the cost of manufacture in con- ventional styrene monomer production. Therefore, to have the largest impact on styrene monomer costs, efforts should be directed at new chemistry using less expensive raw materials. A classical idea for non-traditional styrene synthesis is to use the C4' s, usually meaning butenes or butadiene, for the synthesis. Dixit and Murchison [ 1 ] have recently proposed the use of the crude C4 stream from ethylene * Corresponding author. Tel. ( + 1-517) 8358233, Fax. In this case the butadiene would be removed from the C4 stream by dimerization to 4-vinylcycloh- exene (4-VCH) followed by flashing off the unconverted C4's. The 4-VCH can then be oxidized to styrene in high yield. This process is timely because crude butadiene prices are suppressed due to oversupply. The oversupply fundamentally originates from the fact that butadiene is a by-product of ethylene manufacture and the growth rate for ethylene usage is about twice that of butadiene. This results in a growing surplus of crude C4's especially in areas dependent on cracking liquids such as Europe and the far east. This oversupply depresses the price of butadiene. Furthermore the reactive separation of butadiene by the formation of 4-VCH elim- inates the need for the complex extractive distillation usually used for isolating butadiene at a substantial cost. Large ethylene complexes may have capacities of 1-2 billion lbs/year ethylene. If the complex is fed by hydrocarbon liquids, the potential styrene production from the co-produced crude butadiene is 150-300 MMlbs/year. Modern world scale styrene plants are usually built with capacities of 1 Billion lbs/year or greater. Therefore to build a world scale plant or multiple world scale plants it would be necessary to have 'on purpose' butadiene with the economics similar to those achieved by using crude Ca. Butane is readily available in very large quantities and has a stable, low price partly due to its mandated removal from gasoline during the warm months for vapor pressure considerations. It can be converted to butadiene via conventional dehydrogenation or oxydehydrogenation processes but yields are modest (60%) and the required capital is high [ 2--4]. Furthermore the established Fig. 1. The effect of %K on conversion and selectivities [ 10% butane, 550, GHSV = 336/h] ; (A) selectivity to C4's, (I-7) selectivity to BD, ( ) selectivity to CO, and (O) conversion. G.E. Vrieland, C.B. Murchison/Applied Catalysis A: General 134 (1996) 101-121 103 processes actually convert butane to butenes and then in effect recycle all the butenes back to the front of the reactor for conversion to butadiene. A process that could synthesize principally butadiene in a single pass would be attractive. In view of this we were attracted to some novel work at the Physical-Organic and Coal Chemistry Institute of the Ukrainian Academy of Sciences in Kiev which was using magnesium molybdate catalysts to oxidize butane anaerobically [ 5 ]. These workers claimed single pass selectivities of greater than 70% butadiene and 12% butenes from butane. Assuming the ultimate recycle of butenes, this process could lead to > 80% yield of butadiene from butane. While the Ukrainian work showed breakthrough selectivities for butadiene from butane, the catalysts showed activity for approximately 30 s due to a limited amount of active oxygen available from the catalyst solid. Therefore the commercialization of this technology would require a circulating transport bed reactor to continually replace the oxygen in the solid. This paper discusses catalyst development directed toward creating a practical transport bed catalyst for the butane/butene oxidation reaction. In this report the transport bed is simulated by alternating pulses of butane/He and oxygen/He mixtures over a micro fixed bed reactor. 2. Experimental 2.1. Equipment In a riser reactor the catalyst particles are carried in the reacting gases for a period of less than 30 s. In order to simulate this very short time and facilitate exploration of catalysts and conditions, a pulsed fixed bed reactor was prepared. The catalyst, 10-15 cm3, was held on a porous quartz frit in a quartz tube ( 12 or 19 mm O.D.) and a pulse of butane/helium at atmospheric pressure was fed to the bed for 5-30 s. This was followed by a purge of helium to strip product gases from the bed, then a mixture of O2/He to re-oxidize the catalyst and remove carbon residues, and finally another helium purge. This cycle was repeated automatically. A thermocou- pie was placed in the center of the bed. 2.2. Analysis The products were collected in Saranbags over 10-20 min for later GC analysis and in this way the output of the reactor was integrated over many cycles. An internal standard of N2, Ar or CF4 was co-fed along with the butane mixture. The analyses were performed on a Carle Instruments 111-H gas chromatograph with the refinery gas option. With this system a 1 cm3 sample is injected into a series of columns such that the C3-C~ hydrocarbons are separated on the first column (a modified Porasil C), the C2 and CO2 on the second column (Poropak-Q), and the permanent gases N2, 02, CO, and CH4 on the third column ( 13X molecular sieve). 104 G.E. Vrieland, C.B. Murchison /Applied Catalysis A: General 134 (1996) 101-121 The initial column is backflushed for a qualitative analysis of heavier compounds such as styrene, benzene, and furan. A feed stream analysis was used to determine carbon balances. Where the carbon balance was less than 100% whether due to analytical error or some undetermined by-product, an unknown component was calculated. Selectivities are calculated from the actual change in the butane fed incorporating this unknown as coke. 2.3. Catalyst Preparation Catalysts were prepared by adding a solution of ammonium heptamolybdate in an amount of water sufficient to give a smooth creamy mixture with MgO powder (100-130 m2/g, from Magox Super Premium Grade, Premier Refractories and Chemicals, Inc.). This was dried at 80, calcined slowly up to 600 and crushed to 14-40 mesh particles. Alkali metal hydroxide or carbonate could be included in the molybdate solution or added to the calcined catalyst by incipient wetness of the methanol solution of the hydroxide. The results were similar. Catalyst compositions are usually expressed as wt.-% of MoO3, MgO, K, etc. based on the weights of materials used in the preparation. In some cases these were confirmed by X-ray fluorescence or neutron activation analysis. Samples of pure MgMoO4 were prepared in two ways. The first was by a conventional method of precipitation of magnesium nitrate and ammonium hep- tamolybdate to give a calcined product with 9 m2/g surface area. The second involved decomposition of the salts dissolved in citric acid [ 6 ], which gave a higher surface area, 15.4 m2/g at 550, and a very pure XRD pattern for MgMoO4. 2.4. Characterization Laser Raman spectra were obtained with an Ar+ laser (Lexel, Model 95). The incident laser line was tuned to 514.4 nm and the scattered radiation from the sample was directed into an ISA HG2S double monochromator over 30 min. The in situ Raman cell comprised a spinning sample holder in a quartz cell [7]. The XPS spectra were obtained using a VSW Scientific Instruments UHV cham- ber equipped with a dual anode X-ray source and hemispherical analyzer that has been described in detail elsewhere [8]. The spectra were recorded using A1Kot radiation at a pass energy of 25 eV. The chamber was equipped with a high pressure cell enabling the sample to be isolated from UHV and heated under controlled atmospheres of gas. After reaction the cell was evacuated and the samples returned to UHV for analysis. The catalyst samples were pressed into self-supporting wafers and heated radiatively. G.E. Vrieland, C.B, Murchison/Applied Catalysis A: General 134 (1996) 101-121 105 3. Results 3.1. Catalyst composition Effect of Alkali Although the molybdenum oxide on magnesia catalyst we made initially was active for the oxidation of butane, the selectivities to butadiene were only 50%- 60%. This was somewhat less than the > 70% we expected from the Ukrainian work. Butadiene is a basic compound with strong electron donating capabilities. We theorized that by increasing the basicity of the surface we could enhance the desorption of the product butadiene and thereby increase its selectivity. In fact, we found that small amounts of alkali added to the catalyst preparation did significantly quench the production of COx and simultaneously increase the selectivity to buta- diene. Fig. 1 shows the effect of varying the %K from 0% to 1% by adding methanolic KOH onto a catalyst containing 32.6% MoO3. From 0% to 0.2% K the conversion decreases slightly but the COx decreases from 38% down to 10% and the selectivity to butene + butadiene increases from 50% to over 80%. It appears that alkali metal selectively poisons the production of COx while the production of butene/butadiene remains unaffected. At higher levels of K the conversion decreases and the total selectivity to C4 olefins remains nearly constant although the butenes increase at the expense of butadiene. The optimum level of alkali which gives a maximum in butadiene selectivity is about 0.3 wt.-% K. A similar curve was obtained with equivalent levels of cesium. Table 1 shows that at the similar equivalence levels, 4.4--6.3 atom-% vs. Mo, Cs and Na give the same result as K. The unmodified catalyst gives higher conversions but lower selectivities (column 1 ). This is also true when the space velocity was increased for the blank run to match the conversion of the lower activity alkalized samples (column 5). The results on lithium are compared with potassium in columns 6-8. At the same atom- % ratio lithium is less effective. Even at approximately twice the atom-% ratio it does not match potassium; however, it does give improvement over the unmodified catalyst. Effect of % MoO3 Fig. 2a shows that there is a broad maximum in activity vs. molybdenum loading at about 20 wt.-% MoO3 equivalent in agreement with the work of Dorshenko et al. [ 9]. One would expect the activity to increase with %MOO3 as it does up to 15%. However, the surface area decreases uniformly over the range from 0 to 40 wt.-% MoO3 which partially explains the loss in activity at the higher levels of MOO3. Since selectivity is usually a function of conversion, a series of runs at constant conversion were made by varying space velocity. Fig. 2b shows the effect on selectivity as %MoOa is increased at constant conversion. The result is that above 10% MoO3 the selectivities to butene and butadiene are fairly constant which would suggest that a common catalyst species is present even though its concen- 106 G.E. The conversion data was re-calculated as a specific activity (mmol butane con- verted/unit surface area/g MOO3) and plotted in Fig. 3. Included on this graph are results on two samples of pure MgMoO4. Since the MgMoO4 has relatively low surface area, it has low activity similar to that of the 40% MoO3 samples. However, its specific activity is higher than that of the supported samples. The selectivity is what would be expected of the molybdates without alkali modifiers. This indicates that pure MgMoO4 is active and selective for this reaction. 3.2. In this case 100% butane was run over the catalyst at the usual flow rates for an extended time. Fig. 4a and Fig. 4b show the result of extensive oxygen depletion. We take this to mean that the reaction with surface oxygen is very rapid relative to the straight dehydrogenation of butane and is required to remove a second set of hydrogen atoms resulting in the formation of butadiene. Because the butane conversion at steady state is much lower than that found initially, the surface oxygen reaction is obviously much more facile than the steady state catalytic dehydrogenation. This result makes it very clear that the most attractive oxidative chemistry occurs in a very short time of less than 1-2 min. In fact we find that solid contact times of 5 s or less are optimum. These very short reaction times are feasible only in a transport bed reactor since the practical limit for large switching valves at 500- 600 is a minimum of 10 min. In a separate fluid bed the reduced catalyst would be re-oxidized and the carbon residues removed. In the typical pulse reaction of 5- 10 s, calculations based on the reaction stoichiometry indicate that less than 6%- 20% of the total MoO3 present is reduced from MO6+ to MO5 +. 3.3. Ten cm3 of catalyst was loaded in the laboratory pulse reactor and aged for 350 h. The experimental program was carried out over a five days period to minimize confounding the data by catalyst aging. The independent variables and ranges explored were as follows: butane concentrations of 10%-30%, butane/ helium pulse length of 10-30 s, butane/helium flow rates of 50, 125 and 200 cm3/ G.E. The flows correspond to ambient GHSV's of 300, 750 and 1200 h- 1 or actual gas residence times of about 2, 0.8 and 0.5 s. Table 2 gives the experimental results. The selectivity data is expressed as percent of converted butane carbon in the product molecule. Liner models were developed from this data using the RS 1 Discover software from BBN Software Products Corporation. Fig. 5a and Fig. 5b show conversion and total C4 selectivity as a function of butane concentration. The error bars illustrate the 90% confidence limits of the predictions. Over this butane concentration range the conversion remains constant as it should for a first order reaction in butane. This also implies that the reaction is not being starved for surface oxygen under these conditions. Fig. 6a and Fig. 6b are contour plots of the conversion and butadiene selectivity surfaces for experiments with GHSV of 750 and 1200 h - 1 respectively. The increas- ing space velocity (shorter residence times) has the effect of decreasing the con- version by about 10% with a few percent decline in the direct butadiene selectivity. 3.4. Catalyst life The activity of the molybdenum oxide on magnesia changes with time on stream as shown in Fig. 7. Two different catalysts prepared in the same way but on different sources of MgO illustrate this effect. The first was the typical Magox MgO we normally used for these cata!ysts. The second was based on the Ube MgO [ 10] which consists of small 100 A crystallites of MgO ( 144 m2/g) and show unusual thermal stability. The conversions over both catalysts decrease by around 35% over the first 100 h and then more slowly thereafter. The selectivity to Ca olefins increases initially as the conversion drops and then remains fairly constant. This change is irreversible and is primarily due to the instability of the MgO surface area. The catalyst surface area in this experiment dropped from over 100 to 65 m2/g. A second experiment was run using the very active catalyst based on Ube MgO over a longer period of time while changing the temperature and space velocity to maintain 40% conversion (Fig. 8a). The temperature was raised from 540 to 580 over 500 h giving constant productivity of butadiene (Ibs CJft3/h). After this the space velocity was reduced from 1200 to 650/h which gave the desired 40% conversion but a decrease in productivity. With further increases in temperature the selectivity dropped below 80% and cracking products, ethylene and propene, increased (Fig. 8b). This demonstrated that this catalyst could be operated contin- uously for 2445 h (102 days) and 42 000 cycles. Over this period the activity decreased and the surface area of the fresh catalyst dropped from 163 to 20 m2/g. 3.5. Conclusions The selective oxydehydrogenation of n-butane to butadiene and butenes has been studied over a catalyst consisting of molybdenum on magnesia under conditions where the catalyst supplies the oxygen for the reaction. This was carried out in a small pulsed fixed bed reactor to simulate a riser or other transport bed reactor in which the catalyst is re-oxidized in a separate fluid bed reactor. The results indicate that selectivities of > 80% to butadiene with recycle of butenes at 40%-50% G.E. Vrieland. C.B. Murchison /Applied Catalysis A: General 134 (1996) 101-121 119 conversion per pass are possible and the principal C4 product is butadiene. This is higher selectivity than that obtained from existing catalytic processes. Unlike dehy- drogenation processes, it results in single pass butadiene. The molybdenum on magnesia support is much superior to molybdates on any of the other supports we have examined such as alumina, zinc oxide, lanthanum oxide or titania, or the molybdates of other cations such as calcium, barium or bismuth. Magnesia is sufficiently basic to release the butadiene and yet not form a stable carbonate at the reaction temperature. ( 1 ) There is a maximum in activity which occurs in the range 15%-25% MoO3 on MgO. This level of MoO3 corresponds with the estimated monolayer capacity of the MgO support. However, the form of molybdenum oxide is different from the well studied layers of molybdenum oxide on alumina or titania in that molyb- denum oxide at 550--600 actually reacts with the MgO to form MgMoO4. Although in the fresh catalyst the particles are very small, below the detection limit of XRD or EDX, they can be observed by LRS. At low levels, up to 10% MOO3, they appear to be isolated octahedral molybdate species which are not active or selective. At the level of optimum activity, 10%-25% molybdate, one observes octahedral polymolybdates with Mo--O-Mo bonds. Above 25% both octahedral molybdates and tetrahedral crystalline MgMoO4 is observed by LRS and XANES and these particles have grown to a size that can be observed by XRD. As the catalyst ages accompanied by a decrease in surface area and disappearance in polymolybdates, there is a decrease in activity. (2) Addition of any of the alkali metals in a narrow range of concentration selectively poisons sites responsible for coking and/or combustion without affect- ing the productivity of butadiene. The net result is a significant improvement in selectivity to butadiene/butenes with only a moderate loss in activity. Higher levels of alkali merely reduce the activity without any gain in selectivity. The mechanism for this improvement is thought to consist of selective poisoning of any acid sites either from impurities or from the molybdate. This facilitates the rapid desorption of butadiene. (3) The surface area of magnesia is inherently unstable under reaction conditions of 550-600 in the presence of water vapor. Furthermore, the molybdate particles grow in size during use which results in lower surface area of the active molybde- num. This results in a loss of activity with time on stream. (4) The initial rate of oxygen uptake is much greater than the rate of reduction of the bulk oxide. In practice, only 6%-20% of the potentially reducible oxygen is utilized in the 5-10 s the catalyst is exposed to butane feed. We feel this oxygen corresponds to a very labile form of oxygen, weakly bound to the catalyst surface. XPS and GC/MS studies indicate that MO6+ is reduced to Mo5+. (5) The effect of reaction variables such as butane concentration, temperature, pulse time and GHSV on conversion, selectivity and productivity have been explored in a designed experiment. In the range of 10%-30% butane feed at atmospheric pressure conversion is independent of concentration and there is a 120 G.E. Vrieland, C.B. Murchison / Applied Catalysis A: General 134 (1996) 101-121 small decline in direct butadiene formed. The surface oxygen is not seriously depleted under these conditions. (6) The circulating transport bed reactor provides the brief contact times needed for this reaction and these have been used commercially for many years in fluid catalytic cracking. More recently, they have been used for oxidation reactions such as oxidation of xylene to phthalic anhydride [18], isophthalonitrile [ 19] and oxidation of butane to maleic anhydride [20,21 ]. A significant advantage is that the exothermic re-oxidation can be carried out in a separate bed. High concentrations of butane can be handled safely because the oxygen addition is separated from the hydrocarbon feed which avoids the potential of explosive mixtures. MgO supports are unstable in the presence of high temperature water vapor and do not form high strength spray dried particles with significant surface area. Further work is required directed at surface area stabilization and particle attrition. We will report on some of this work in a future publication. In this paper we report a catalyst which provides 40%–50% conversion of n-butane at 80% selectivity to butadiene and the n-butenes when exposed to 5–10 s pulses of n-butane followed by air regeneration. The optimum catalyst consists of 15%–25% MoO3 dispersed on MgO. The addition of small amounts of alkali metal compounds are used to minimize the production of carbon oxides.
